ACM WIT Students Chapter
The Wentworth Association of Computing Machinery is open to all students. The ACM WIT Students Chapter is a club affiliated with the official ACM organization. Much like our parent organization, our goal is to promote education and research in the computer science, cybersecurity, computer networking, and computer engineering fields. The ACM WIT Students Chapter differs from a plethora of other clubs in that we are chartered by ACM (the Association for Computing Machinery). ACM), ACM is the largest body of computer scientists globally. The organization’s objective is to facilitate communication and collaboration within a university's computer science community and with the computing community at large. Thus, by leveraging the opportunities provided by ACM, we focus on hands-on projects and experiences, with workshops and mini lectures given by professors and industry experts.

American Foundry Society
The Wentworth American Foundry Society is open to all students. The American Foundry Society (AFS) is a professional, technical and trade association for foundries and the broader metal casting industry. The society promotes the interests of foundries to policymakers, provides training for foundry workers, and supports research and technological advancements in foundry science and manufacturing. AFS represents ferrous and nonferrous foundries based in North America, as well as industry suppliers and end-users of metal castings from around the world. The society has individual and corporate members across 48 countries, organized into regional chapters and student chapters in the United States, Canada and Mexico. AFS presents Metalcasting Congress, a yearly industry conference, as well as CastExpo, a trade show and exposition that occurs every three years.

Transition Programs Our transition programs provide new students with the support and resources necessary to get off to a successful start at Wentworth. New Student Orientation is a two-day overnight program held during June that allows all first-year students to explore campus and meet classmates, faculty members, and staff. Wentworth Opening Week takes place over the course of four days prior to the start of the fall semester, and helps prepare students to make the most of the academic and extracurricular opportunities that exist at Wentworth. Additional programs for new transfer students and international students are offered to address the unique elements of these students' transition to Wentworth. Dean of Students Office
The Dean of Students Office acts as a resource, referral agent, and advocate for students so they may live and learn successfully throughout their Wentworth experience. Whether you need advice or support on academic or personal matters, we can help you access the resources and solutions you need. In the past, we have helped students with such concerns as missing a significant number of classes due to illness or injury, experiencing financial hardships, or difficulties with the transition into college life. These are among the services and resources we can provide: Receive support for personal, financial, or academic matters Submit an Absence Notification Request Report concerning or threatening behaviors Receive information about the Wentworth Student Handbook Fulfilling your Jury Duty service as a student File an official concern/complaint at the Institute Learn about the Student Emergency Fund Access the Wentworth Supply Closet Submit a Voluntary Disclosure of Physical Access Needs Form Seek assistance to request a Medical Leave of Absence Report a violation of the Student Code of Conduct Receive information regarding Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) The Dean of Students Office also oversees compliance with the Student Code of Conduct and the processes used to administer and enforce it throughout the Wentworth community. The office also provides assistance with Student Code of Conduct violations

IEEE-Eta Kappa Nu
The IEEE EKA at Wentworth is open to all students. IEEE-Eta Kappa Nu (IEEE-HKN), the honor society of IEEE, promotes excellence in the profession and in education with ideals of Scholarship, Character and Attitude. HKN promotes professional accomplishment, service to others, and leadership development for students and professionals in electrical engineering, computer engineering, and other IEEE fields of interest. At Wentworth, our members get chance to attend student leadership conferences, apply for scholarships, join in our Guest Speaker, Workshop events which the speakers and instructors are invited from the industry with leadership roles and faculty/staff members. We also do talk show which we invite alumni and current outstanding students come share with us their successes and failures. Moreover, the society offers tutoring some courses each semester, technical lab skill lectures and related workshop to prepare students for their co-ops, connect students with recruiters. ------------------------------------------------ Founded in 1904 by Maurice L.Carr and nine fellow students at the University of Illinois, Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) was originally established to help electrical engineering graduates find employment and gain footholds in their careers. Today, IEEE-HKN is 200,000+ members strong and is the honor society for IEEE, the world’s largest technical professional organization for advancing technology for humanity. IEEE-HKN is still dedicated to encouraging and recognizing academic excellence, impeccable character and the positive attitude needed to lead and serve others. IEEE-HKN develops promising young professionals into resilient, collaborative, global citizens and is with them through every step of their professional journey. IEEE-HKN offers access to countless experiences, opens doors to a lifetime of learning, and encompasses a global network of visionary leaders with heart.

National Electrical Contractors Association (WIT Student Chapter)
The National Electrical Contractors Association (NECA) at Wentworth welcomes ALL STUDENTS! Our club provides exceptional opportunities to engage with leading electrical contractors, not only from the Boston area but from across the United States. Each year, our Student NECA chapter participates in an electrical-focused challenge presented by ECIC, competing against more than fifteen colleges nationwide, each representing their regional NECA chapters. This challenge incorporates real-world construction management and engineering concepts, allowing students to gain hands-on experience in the proposal process from an electrical contractor’s perspective. In addition to our annual group project, we offer industry-related trips, including conventions, site visits, and networking events with electrical professionals. We also host guest speakers and monthly meetings (with dates and times varying each semester) to keep members engaged and informed. Join us to expand your professional network, gain valuable industry insights, and explore potential career opportunities in the electrical field!

OneWIT
It's 3 a.m. You're up late finding more sources for a group project when you get a text from a friend. You open the message and it says:  "This is the worst night of my life. I've been crying for hours. I can't deal with this stupid life anymore." You want to respond quickly, but hesitate…What can you say? What if things you say only make it worse? What if your friend is thinking of…You don't even want to go there. You want to help, but you're just not sure how… One WIT’s training program gives you the tools to handle this kind of situation. The primary goal of OneWIT is to expand and enrich the campus support network so every member of our community has people looking out for each other — and all know where to go for help when things get tough. To achieve this end, we have a few secondary goals. Knowledge. To give you information about common student struggles, and what you and others can do to help. Skills. To help you develop your helping skills, particularly the skill of empathetic listening and responding, through practice. Perspectives. To provide a safe place to look at issues facing college students from a variety of viewpoints and find a way to think about these without perpetuating stigmas. Connection. To build meaningful connections, both between you and us at the Center for Wellness, and between you and your fellow trainees.

Society of Women Engineers
SWE Overview: The Society of Women Engineers (SWE) is a not-for-profit educational and service organization that empowers women to succeed and advance in engineering and be recognized for their life-changing contributions as engineers and leaders. SWE is the driving force that establishes engineering as a highly desirable career for women through an exciting array of training and development programs, networking opportunities, scholarships alongside outreach and advocacy activities. Founded 1950 Objectives Goal 1: Professional excellence – SWE will develop women engineers at all stages of their personal and professional lives. Goal 2: Globalization – SWE will be recognized as a global, inclusive organization that promotes diversity and inclusion and serves women engineers wherever they are. Goal 3: Advocacy – SWE will advocate for the inclusion and success of women, both present and prospective, in engineering and technology. Goal 4: SWE will champion diversity in the engineering and technology professions and promote an inclusive environment. Members Over 40,000 individual members who are collegiates and professionals. Levels SWE has over 300 collegiate member sections and 100 professional member sections.   SWE Mission: Empower women to achieve full potential in careers as engineers and leaders, expand the image of the engineering and technology professions as a positive force in improving the quality of life, and demonstrate the value of diversity and inclusion.   SWE Vision: A world with gender parity and equality in engineering and technology.   SWE Core Values:  Integrity We aspire to the highest level of ethical behavior as evidenced by honesty and dignity within our personal and professional relationships and responsibilities. Inclusive Environment We embrace diversity in its broadest interpretation and commit to creating an inclusive environment for all our members and stakeholders. We value the contributions of a diverse membership, which enables SWE to achieve its full potential. Mutual Support We provide an organization that fosters mentoring and the development of professional and personal networks. Professional Excellence  We professionally conduct our activities, demonstrating and demanding the highest standards of business practices. Trust  We share a common definition of success with open, transparent access to information, building mutual respect and confidence in the abilities of those with whom we lead, serve, and partner.

Success Studio
At Wentworth, we are wholeheartedly committed to student success. In support of this mission, the Success Studio acts as the central hub dedicated to helping our students thrive through Student Success Advising, Academic Support and Tutoring, and Student Accessibility Services. If you have any questions, please email successstudio@wit.edu. To speak with any of our staff please make an appointment through EAB Navigate. Student Success Advising Student Success Advisors (SSAs) support students in the transition to college by assisting with degree planning, course selection, academic coaching, and connecting students to campus-wide resources. The Role of a Student Success Advisor: - Coaching Transition and Success - Connecting to resources - Registration and Academic Planning Connecting with a Student Success Advisor: - Students can connect with their SSA through EAB Navigate, via email, or in person by stopping by the Success Studio to make an appointment. Academic Support Academic Support links students with professional and peer tutors. Tutoring services are available for all Wentworth students at no cost. For any questions geared toward Academic Support email us at academicsupport@wit.edu Tutoring Options: - Tutoring is available one-on-one by appointment in-person and remotely via Zoom. Tutoring is also available in drop-in group review sessions. - Check out the Academic Support section on our webpage each semester for a list of drop-in group review sessions. Scheduling a tutoring appointment: Students can book tutoring appointments from 9 am to 8 pm Monday through Friday. Student Accessibility Services Student Accessibility Services (SAS) provides support and accommodations for students with disabilities to fully participate in the college experience at Wentworth. Accommodation Eligibility: - Students with physical, medical, psychiatric, learning disabilities and other diagnoses are eligible to utilize SAS to arrange for reasonable accommodations and seek ongoing support at any point in their Wentworth career. Meeting with SAS  - To get started, students can fill out the Accommodation Request Form found on our webpage and schedule a meeting through EAB Navigate, or email us at access@wit.edu - Meetings can be held in-person, remotely via Zoom, or by phone call. - Registration and Academic Planning

Wentworth believes strongly in that being a member of a Division III athletics team can be an invaluable part of the overall educational experience and is an opportunity to build responsibility, pride, and character in an individual. Wentworth Events Board
Wentworth Events Board (WEB) is responsible for planning and hosting most of the events on and off Wentworth's campus for Wentworth students. Our past events have included rock climbing, laser tag, movie nights, paint nights, and game nights that happen on both weeknights and weekends. WEB also hosts WEB Wednesday every Wednesday inside Beatty Hall at lunch time, providing fun crafts or snacks for students. Welcome to the Wentworth Poker Club! The Wentworth Poker Club is open to all students. About Us Welcome to the official page of the Wentworth Poker Club, where we bring the thrill of poker to the heart of Wentworth Institute of Technology. Women@Wentworth
The goal of the Women@Wentworth Undergraduate Leadership Experience is to connect students to a diverse community of mentors and role models as they catalyze their career potential and develop their unique abilities to lead. Students customize the their leadership pathway to align with their personal and professional goals as they learn to optimize their strengths, build networks, and cultivate tenacity for a lifetime of success.  What is W@W UG Leadership Program? W@W UG Leadership Program is a customized, experience-based, learning pathway designed to bring recognition to the in-demand, career-readiness skills that students are building in and outside of the classroom through the leadership activities they already do in ANY context on campus. Whether they are engaging in a women-focused activity or leading an all-identity club or organization, they can earn Wentworth-verified digital badges and a certificate for their efforts. By tracking their experiences and reflecting on the lessons they have learned, students are issued a digital badge for each year of completion. Why does Wentworth offer identity-based programs? The value of Identity-Affinity settings is supported through extensive research and provide a unique context for learning that enhances access to creativity, drives innovation, and builds career advancement. Any developmental gains made transfer to all-identity settings with benefits for the individual and those they interact with. Research backed benefits include: (1) increased leadership self-efficacy (“I can do this!”); (2) increased goodness of fit (I belong here.); (3) decreased identity threat (“Even if I am in the non-dominant group around here, I will succeed!”); (4) increased psychological safety (“I am safe, fit in, and can take risks.”); (5) decreased emotional labor (“I can relax and focus on being my best self.”). How does this differ from other women identity-based organizations on campus? W@W UG Leadership Program is not a club or an organization, it is a micro-credential learning pathway, that allows students to track and showcase the career-readiness competencies via Brightspace, that they gain from activities taking place outside the classroom. W@W UG also hosts and co-sponsors numerous events and activities throughout the year, that are open to all students, providing ample opportunities for any student, regardless of other activity or club affiliation, to fulfill the badge requirements. Who can sign up for this program? All students, regardless of gender identity, are welcome to participate. The program provides a custom framework that allows students to make it their own. Students can begin the program at any point during their time at Wentworth and complete the program prior to graduation, however we encourage students to enroll in their first year at Wentworth to maximize the benefits and experience. Why would students want to participate? The program aims to provide students with an opportunity to: (1) connect to a diverse community of leaders, mentors, and role models. (2) Create and showcase a portfolio of developmental experiences that they customize to their unique personal and professional goals. (3) Follow a self-directed path to develop leadership skills, build networks, and cultivate tenacity for a lifetime of SUCCESS. (4) Earn verified micro-credentials + an exclusive graduation stole! What is a digital badge? Like a diploma, a digital badge serves as a visual proof validating credibility, competency, and earning requirements of a specific program. Once you complete and submit requirements on Brightspace, you will be issued a digital badge that can be displayed on your LinkedIn, resumes, or other digital signatures. How do I get started? Simply self-enroll in Women@Wentworth Undergraduate course Brightspace to join our mailing list and start earning your badges today!
